benchmark_details.name: Large Language Models for Pedestrian Safety: An Application to Predicting Driver Yielding Behavior at Unsignalized Intersections
benchmark_details.overview: This paper presents a novel application of multimodal LLMs to predict driver yielding behavior toward pedestrians at unsignalized intersections, using over 3,000 annotated interactions across 18 intersection sites.

purpose_and_intended_users.goal: To evaluate the capacity of LLMs to predict driver yielding behavior at unsignalized intersections and provide actionable insights for deploying LLMs in pedestrian safety systems.
purpose_and_intended_users.limitations: The extensive preprocessing required for video data hampers real-time deployment.

data.source: Open source Minnesota driver-pedestrian dataset consisting of interactions recorded at unsignalized intersections.

methodology.calculation: Evaluation based on predictions from various models against a benchmark dataset.
methodology.interpretation: High accuracy indicates good model performance in predicting yielding behavior.
methodology.baseline_results: Logistic Regression achieved 88.08% accuracy as a baseline model.
methodology.validation: Results validated against a comparative analysis of model performance.
